issues.description: The problem statement (and UML) specify getTotalNumberOfStudents() should return an int, but the solution implementation declares getTotalNumberOfStudents() returning a StudentCount object (and the solution adds a StudentCount class). This is a return-type/signature mismatch: students following the specification/UML will implement an int-returning method, while the provided solution uses a custom wrapper type. This inconsistency can confuse students (which type is correct?), and makes the solution repository an unreliable reference for the expected signature and return type.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the return type consistent across artifacts. Preferably align the solution with the problem/UML by changing Lecture.getTotalNumberOfStudents() in the solution to return an int (e.g. return numberOfInscribedStudents + numberOfGuestStudents) and update any callers (getNameAndTotalNumberOfStudents(), getNumberOfStudentsPerTutor()) to use the int return value. Remove the StudentCount class from the solution or explicitly document and add StudentCount to the problem statement and template if the wrapper type was intentional. This ensures students and the reference solution use the same method signature.

issues.description: The problem statement (and UML) specifies getTotalNumberOfStudents() should return an int (the total number of students). In the solution, getTotalNumberOfStudents() returns a StudentCount object (and a separate StudentCount class is introduced). This creates a mismatch between the expected type in the exercise specification and the identifier/type used in the solution, likely confusing students who expect a primitive int result and who are guided by the UML and textual instructions.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem/UML by making getTotalNumberOfStudents() return an int. Concretely, change the Lecture.getTotalNumberOfStudents() signature to 'public int getTotalNumberOfStudents()' and return numberOfInscribedStudents + numberOfGuestStudents. Remove the StudentCount class (or keep it but use it only internally) and update any callers (e.g., getNameAndTotalNumberOfStudents() and getNumberOfStudentsPerTutor()) to use the int return value. Alternatively, if introducing StudentCount is intentional, update the problem statement and UML to document the StudentCount type and its API so students are not surprised.
